intro: Carex ligulata, commonly known as the narrow-leaved sedge, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to temperate regions of the Northern Hemisphere. It belongs to the genus Carex in the family Cyperaceae, characterized by its grass-like appearance and spike-like inflorescences. The plant typically grows in moist to wet soils, often found in wetlands, marshes, and along stream banks. Its leaves are narrow, grass-like, and often have a bluish-green hue, while its flowers are small and clustered in dense spikes. Carex ligulata plays an important ecological role in stabilizing soil and providing habitat for various invertebrates.
